Share: Digg Facebook StumbleUpon Part 2: Windmill Hill and West Overton After Rains © 2008 by Linda Moulton Howe “M y eye was attracted toward Lockeridge about a mile north of the formation. ‘Oh, my God, it's one of those aerial, flickering mirrors!’” - L inda Moulton Howe, Reporter & Editor, Earthfiles.com R ain was heavy in Wiltshire County, England, even flooding roads, the first week of August 2009. But at Windmill Hill near Avebury Trusloe, a 350-foot-diameter pattern of circles on rings with complex dumbbells in the center was reported on August 6. Aerial image © 2009 by Frank Laumen, Visible Signs.de . More information and images: Cropcircleconnector.com. U pper left purple circle marks location of Windmill Hill near the ancient stones of Avebury. The lower right purple circle marks the location of West Overton near Lockeridge, both in the English county of Wiltshire. R eturn to Part 1 August 17, 2009 Albuquerque, New Mexico - The morning of August 6, 2009, when I and others first went to the remarkable Windmill Hill formation, it was still raining after

nights and days of rain. But the next day on August 7, 2009, the clouds lifted, sun came through and Charles Mallett took his 20-foot-pole and camera to the Windmill Hill pattern. August 7, 2009 - Pole Shots At Windmill Hill Near Avebury Trusloe, Wiltshire County, England Images © 2009 by Charles Mallett, Silent Circle Research Centre
August 8, 2009 - West Overton Near Lockeridge, Wiltshire County, England

N ear the center of the map is West Overton near Lockeridge and near the center of where most 2009 English crop formations emerged (purple centers). The next morning of August 8, 2009, Jaime Maussan from Mexico City and I received news that another new formation had been seen from the air at West Overton near Lockeridge. We headed there and met up with Charles and others, all of us trying to get into the fresh formation before it was trampled by tourists or cut out by the farmer. 450 -foot-long geometry at West Overton near Lockeridge, Wiltshire, England, reported August 8, 2009. Aerial image © 2009 by Lucy Pringle. More information and images: Cropcircleconnector.com. The 450-foot-long wheat formation had three different circle centers. The one furthest to the east (bottom circle in above aerial) looked as if water had swirled all the pieces into a liquid, organic whole, including seven circles of wheat arranged around the center.

L inda Moulton Howe examining wheat plants that had straightened seed heads compared to stiff, curled tops of mature wheat in unaffected crop behind her. Foreground is one of seven circular “fans” placed around center of eastern most circle in the 450-foot-long West Overton formation near Lockeridge, Wiltshire, England, reported August 8, 2009. D owned wheat flowing like water to form seven fanned out circles around two fountains in the center of the eastern most circle of the West Overton formation reported August 8, 2009. Pole image © 2009 by Charles Mallett, Sile nt Circle Rese arch Ce ntre . As I stood marveling at the liquid gracefulness of what should have been stiff, mid-August wheat, my eye was attracted toward Lockeridge about a mile north of the formation. “Oh, my God, it's one of those aerial, flickering mirrors!” After a few seconds of stunned staring at the white, flickering light moving along the tops of the wheat in the field between the new formation and Lockeridge church, I grabbed for my video camera. But by the time I was focusing the eyepiece, I couldn't see the white, moving sparkle anymore. Those flickering, aerial “mirrors” were seen and videotaped before and after crop formations in the early 1990s. This was the first one I have seen in daylight with my eyes. Are the flickering mirror lights “intelligent plasmas of unknown origin,” as Italian astronomer Massimo Teodorani, has asked in his 1990s research of the Hessdalen, Norway, mysterious mountain lights?

O ne of four corner grapeshot circles with fountain dotting the West Overton wheat formation first reported on August 8, 2009. Image © 2009 by Linda Moulton Howe. Re-oriented Growth Nodes - Biophysical and Biochemical Changes E longated and reoriented growth nodes were caused by biophysical and biochemical changes in the wheat plants. Biophysicist W. C. Levengood hypothesizes that a spinning plasma vortex containing microwave and electrical energies comes downward from the atmosphere and rapidly heats and collapses some plants, affecting growth nodes, while leaving other plants standing. Image © 2009 by Charles Mallett, Silent Circle Research Centre. August 8, 2009 - West Overton Pole Shots

M ore straightened seed heads in flowing, downed wheat of formation in contrast to stiff, curled seed heads in standing crop. Background is village of Lockeridge, Wiltshire, England. Pole image © 2009 by Charles Mallett, Sile nt Circle Re search Centre . C ircular bands around two central fountains in far western circle of West Overton wheat formation, above and below, reported August 8, 2009. Pole image © 2009 by Charles Mallett, Sile nt Circle Re se arch Ce ntre . P ole shot of far western circular bands © 2009 by Frank Laumen, Visible Signs.de .

W oven center of larger central circle in the West Overton 450-foot-long wheat formation reported August 8, 2009. Pole image © 2009 by Stuart Dike, Cropcircleconnector.com. W oven central larger circle composed of 90-degree overlapping swaths of wheat. Pole image © 2009 by Charles Mallett, Sile nt Circle Re search Centre .
